It came in a double espresso cup, roughly 4oz, just as it should be served and is served across the world except for the US -_- I am so tired of getting a 24oz watered down cup of bitter nasty because a cafe owner failed to google 'how to make an americano'. Come on people. But Starving Artist does it right, and they do it deliciously. Coffee has an amazing taste and they know how to get that beautiful, creamy froth out of their espresso. If you love coffee, it's a must here. And even if you don't, now's your chance to start!

The food. We went here twice and since I'm not gluten-free, the first time we went I ordered regular wheat waffles and my girlfriend, who is, got the gluten-free. The second time, we wanted to share a savory and sweet so I got GF waffles as well. And I can honestly say, I preferred the GF to the wheat! I found them to actually be airier, lighter and crispier on the outside than the regular. And after eating half an order piled with eggs and a superb hollandaise, and half an order with Nutella and fruit, I appreciated not feeling weighed down by the waffles themselves. But either way, you honestly can't go wrong. And did I mention, they serve breakfast till 5?? We walked in unknowingly at 4:30 and were handed a breakfast menu to our great delight. How perfect was that?! Went back the very next day.

I've been to Starving Artist a number of times (Lansdowne location before it closed and once to the St Clair location) and thought I'd leave a review of my most recent visit.

The St. Clair location is really lovely - bright and airy and makes for a really nice atmosphere.  The staff is lovely - friendly and smiley :)

4 of us got there at 12:45pm on a Sunday, expecting a long wait, but we were seated fairly quickly.  The groups of 2 seemed to have a longer wait.

We all got waffle dishes of various kinds - the veggie waffle sandwich received a 6/10, the Hitchhiker got good reviews as did the breakfast benny (potato waffles). 

I got the B.Breakfast - potato waffles with poached eggs, candied bacon, hollandaise and chives, with a side of fruit and greens.   The eggs were perfectly poached, and the fruit was great.  The hollandaise was ok (I like it a little more lemony and flavourful).  Unfortunately, the mainstay of the establishment is the waffle, and in this case, the potato waffle.  I remember these being slightly larger and thinner and therefore crispier.  Today, it felt like I was eating mashed potatoes for breakfast.  

This may be ok for some, but the texture took away from my enjoyment of the meal.  Next time I'll get the regular waffles (I poached some from my mum's plate - so light and fluffy!)

My other gripe is with the vanilla almond latte.  It came in a tall glass (yay!) but was really watery, and not like a latte at all.  I suspect it was a watered down Americano with vanilla syrup and almond milk froth.  Very disappointing.   Had the 3 others I dined with not enjoyed their meals, I would have given this review 2 stars simply because of this terrible beverage.

Here's the question: will I go back?  Because it's close to both my yoga and spin studios, I suspect I will, but I certainly won't get the potato waffles or any lattes.

This is one of the first brunch places i tried when moving to Toronto.  Their potato waffles are amazing and the amount you get will keep you full till late dinner.  I would recommend to go a little earlier before the brunch rush because the line will be long and slow.

Their eggs benedict was delicious.  Kind of sad that they only had maple bacon as an option.  Would have preferred bacon that isn't sweetened.
One of my top 3 brunch places in the city. The mashed potato waffles are heaven on Earth.

Service is extremely slow, the waitress had green nail polish that was extremely cracked. When I tried to order a smoothie and cancel it before it was made, she did not cancel it and instead lied to me and said they already had made the smoothie when I watched them make it 5 minutes after I asked to cancel my order. I'm actually sitting here right now typing this review because it has taken that long for me to get my food, solid 35 minutes for eggs. Right now everyone in the room is complaining about the service. A table of two has had only one meal delivered and is waiting for his food. The food is coming out one by one. This waitress clearly needs a retrain and the staff are extremely inexperienced. This local is not  planning on returning any time soon.

Amazing! 
First let's start with the ambiance... They are a very casual hipster/dive bar/cafe with  board games in the back minus Snakes and Lattes $5 cover. Speaking of lattes though, theirs are insanely good; the  marshmallow latte is my fave and the even roast a marshmallow on top.

The nachos here are a little stoke of genius. Instead of piling the tortilla chips high and plopping toppings on to (creating an uneven and let's face it boring eating experience) they lay a layer of them on a baking sheet add the toppings and repeat. The result is goodness in every bite and no boring virgin chips buried at the bottom of the stack!

Ironically I am not too fussy on waffles (which is most of what thy serve). I've had one savory one in sandwich form and it was a bit on the soggy side underneath.

Mmm I really enjoyed the B Benny and the Chicken Bacon club.  The potato waffles are like mashed potatos cooked in a waffle iron, so the outsides are crisp while the insides are fluffy. The caramelized bacon compliments the eggs benny really well without being too sweet. The Chicken Bacon club was good, no extra seasoning or condiments needed, but the bottom waffle got soggy from sitting on the plate. I was surprised they had almond milk lattes as not many establishments offer almond milk, but the vanilla almond latte was good.The salad on the side could use a bit of balsamic vinegar though and my friend agreed that the mustard-y potato salad tasted exactly like Costcos.

The wait wasn't bad on a Thursday morning and there was a staff of two. The waitess was really friendly. Ask for the bill split first as she had to split the bill manually at the resgister for us (oops!).

I'm sad that the Ossington location closed down, so we trekked south to this location where the hipster vibe is more pronounced. The food is still as good as ever and the seating is way more spacious. Cash only though, so be sure you got enough before you get in line!

Went in on a Tuesday, great service and speed. The food - freaking incredible. We both had a variation on a Benny and could not believe those potato waffles. Got a regular waffle on the side and it made me want a second breakfast. Can't wait to come back!

A friend of mine who visited Toronto a few months before I did, recommend I checkout this place. It was AMAZING! By far one of my favorite places to eat in Toronto.

My friends and I stayed in the Entertainment District for Caribana. It was about a 20 min drive from us, but we for sure didn't mind it after we got there. 

The place is small so, expect a wait if they're busy. I believe we went on a Sunday morning and because it was 5 of us we waited about 20 mins.

I STRONGLY recommend the potatoe waffles. They are to die for. We were skeptical as Americans, but after we left it was all we talked about! The Waffle bacon wasn't that great because the bacon is so thin you can hardly taste it through the waffle. We also didn't like the beans with our breakfast but, that could just be us as Americans.

The mimosa was bomb! I can't wait to go back!!

Bacon Waffles with a side of whipped cream.

That should really be all I need to say about this place but I'll elaborate a little more.

No matter what time of day you come here you're going to have waffles. My friends and I started with a round of drinks but quickly ordered the bacon waffles (don't forget the side of whipped cream, seriously, don't). We were there fairly late in the evening but I needed something more substantial to soak up the doubles I was drinking as I hadn't had dinner. So I ordered the sliders.

These aren't just normal sliders, they're...you guessed it...waffle sliders. Instead of buns they use mini waffles. I was a little weary at first but took the plunge. Delicious. The side of potato salad was also really great.

The service was ok. The server seemed to get a little pre-occupied with a large group that showed up so it took a little longer than we would have liked to get another round. Also, when we were ready to go she passed by our table twice, noticing that we were done, but still didn't offer to bring the bill.

So I've never been to any of the starving artist locations before so this was my first experience at this very popular waffle spot. 

I got there at around 11 am with 3 other people. We waited in line for almost a damn hour. There was ONE server. I'm sure there should've been more but maybe someone called in sick? Regardless it was a mad house in there and they really need management in here to sort things out as things could've been a lot more efficient. Sitting parties of 2 at 4-seater tables for example, ugh! No one should have to wait an hour for brunch!!! Anyway I felt bad for the one server she was so busy and tried her best. 

I ordered the loaded potato waffles which were two potato waffles with cheese bacon and sour cream. It was damn delicious!!!! Very filling and tasty but the side salad it came with was weak. Wilted greens with barely any dressing. 

With better service and a little more effort on the sides dishes (salad and fruit) this place would be amazing. The waffles live up to the hype but would not go back if I had to wait an hour to sit.
Sandwiched between rows of houses this little gem if a restaurant is totally worth the trek. Highly recommend their potato waffles, and be prepared to stand in line for the brunch rush.

If you want to eat waffles for brunch, this place is for you. if you don't, go somewhere else because everything on the menu here, sweet or savory, is served in, on, or with waffles. The waffles are done well, but everything else here that goes with the waffles, from the eggs to the bacon to the hollandaise is pretty generic and underwhelming. Like others have mentioned, the poached eggs look like they were microwaved in a mold and they taste OK only. Presentation is nice but again, nothing here that sets it apart from some of the better brunch places in the area. The place also seems very popular with the 12-15 age range for some reason, so take what you want away from that. 

Food 3/5
Service 3/5
Atmosphere 2/5
Decor 3/5

Service wasn't the best, but food was really tasty.
I don't like to mess with classics, but I thought Starving Artist's version of eggs benny on potato waffles were really delicious. Extremely rich, though. My order was the Hitchhiker - which was also great.

The service was a little lackluster. The food took a while to arrive, and when I ordered a coffee I was brought an Americano and told "this is our coffee". I didn't really get a heads up on that, I might've asked for something different! Luckily I really enjoyed the Americano so I wasn't too bothered. All in all: tasty food, OK service, will return but only if I'm in the area. We went out of our way to try this place because we loooove breakfast :)

Also, a lot of the dishes are waffle-y. I'm not a waffle guy, more of a savory breakfast lover. So... if you're into waffles... you might wanna give STarving ARtist a go

I honestly had an overall negative experience here. The food, to be fair, was decent for the price, but the service was absolutely tragic. We had to wait almost 30 minutes for the staff to make 3 waffles, and the server, scotty,  ignored us for most of our stay at starving artist. In addition, the entire wait staff was super awkward and everytime they interacted with us I felt very uncomfortable (long pauses in between responses etc.) In addition, in the end, it took them about 15 minutes to tell us that they didn't take credit cards and another 15 minutes for them to take our money. In addition the water served was just from the sink which was disappointing. Overall, the horrible service negated the quality of the food resulting in one out of five stars

Great for brunch, love their breakfast Benny, I'd recommend as the side you stick with the fruit, the potato salad tastes like store bought..must try both the potato and bacon waffles, they are both amazing.
Another brunch....another great experience!  Love the Hitchhiker and the berry fruit flavoured tea is awesome when you are caffeine'd out!
Massive potato waffle stacked with veggies. Super yummy and enough to share. Only reason why it gets a four is because ambience could be better. Super friendly staff.

Just north of Bloor and Lansdowne, Starving Artist's got more waffles than an economists convention. I dare you to not ingest a waffle here. If you open your mouth, there is a 73% chance that a waffle will fall in. Seriously.

It's bigger than it seems inside, with tables going all the way back. And though it wasn't yet set up, their front patio was tantalizing. The decor inside is probably best described as Hipster Gaufre. I dug the heavily tagged plaster lions, the endless waffle kitsch, and the pyramid of breakfast cereals. (Kellogg's I might add.)

Their brunch menu features the wafer-iron-wonder in a bevy of transmogrifications. There are bennies, mini-waffles with fruit, potato waffles, gluten-free waffles, even something called waffle bacon. For me the choice was obvious: smoked salmon eggs benedict on mini waffs. Pretty, pretty, pretty fantastic. With a side of baked beans in maple syrup it was a breakfastacular combination. We washed it all down with a monster-sized french press; $5! (Also: try the PB and B smoothie. It's thicker than a kid on a football scholarship.)

Service was polite, but deliberately paced. They do have debit here, but after a few failed attempts we scrounged together some cash. You have to wait for your bill here (and you will wait) but you pay at the counter. Everyone who works here is also much cooler than you. Don't feel bad about it.

Oh, and apparently, this place is also a hot little spot at night which would explain the full bar and Amsterdam brews on tap. I wonder if they crank those waffle irons after dark too... 
 
Obligatory Title Pun: WAFL-copters!

Menu Readability: A typewriter font I'm none too fond of, but it's plenty readable.

Need to mention: No parking on Paton Rd from midnight to 7pm. Figured this out the hard way.

What this place teaches me about myself: I now officially hate the word "waffle."

3.5/5 stars. 

It's a decent brunch place. We waited for 45 minute before getting a place to sit down - your typical brunch wait. 

They're definitely known for their potato waffle (B. Benny).  It's actually just okay - definitely not bad but it's kind of like a mashed potato with the poached egg. A little too mushy for my liking in terms of texture. The potato salad and salad that came with was decent too. I don't think this was amazing by any means. The potato waffle was just worth trying but it's not absolutely mind blowing. Service was good. No refills for coffees (only Americanos). 

Cash only.

After returning from a trip, we made a decision to be brunch-venturous.  Let's hit up some new places!  & so - we ventured into the land of waffles.

No disappointment here.  We got here around noon, feeling a bit lazy & thinking we would have to wait but we snuck in right before the crowds arrived.  Turns out we weren't the only ones who slept in!

My Waffle Benny was delicious - light fluffy waffles in place of where english muffins might normally be.  The poached eggs were eerily perfect in shape & texture.  Their Hollandaise wasn't as zing-y as I prefer but as I've mentioned I'm a fan of zest until the bitter end...

Great Americano(s), smiley service.  Bring your epi-pen - there are bees a-plenty (I blame the syrup).

Really close to the subway station by the same name as the street. It's in the middle of a residential district but was very busy. There's a front and rear patio, though there were a lot of wasps about. The inside was very hot-the doors were wide open and there was a big fan so no AC I'm guessing. 
The food was good though! Big portions! I got 4 mini waffles ($7) with bananas ($2) and strawberries ($2). It came with a side of fruit and a side salad both of which were fresh and good. I got one of the simpler dishes but there are some creative waffles including a waffle eggs Benedict. I recommend the place for breakfast, just perhaps go when it's not so hot/humid.

I have to say, I was apprehensive about stopping in given their pretty poor Yelp grade, but I was really happy with my brunch! 

My friend and I wandered in after Emma's was closed unexpectedly for an electrical problem. The line was pretty long but moved fast; we were sitting at a cozy corner table with coffee in under 30 minutes. Score! 

Everything on the menu at Starving Artist is either contained within, or on top of, a waffle (genius). I decided on the Breakfast Waffles: two mini potato waffles topped with caramelized bacon, poached eggs and (what else?) maple syrup. Each of the egg dishes is served with salad and your choice of fruit or potato salad (I went with the fruit). Everything was delicious. The bacon was crisp and the perfect mix of sweet and savory, the eggs were poached to perfection and the waffle melted in my mouth. We tried a mini S'Mores Waffle for dessert - nothing special - but a tasty bite to finish the meal. 

We had great, speedy service and tasty dishes with lots of flavor. Give the St. Clair branch another go! I certainly will.

Disclaimer: Please note, this post is a few months delayed, things may have changed since.

I used to go out for brunch on a regular basis.  My first experience with Starving Artist was at their old Lansdowne location, north of Bloor.  The place was always, always, (reiterating again) always packed!  It was definitely worth it.

The Potato waffles always go amazing with the Eggs Benny!

At the St. Clair location, I agree with previous yelp posts. The food takes a long time to arrive at your table, much longer than we used to wait at the Lansdowne location.
Great waffles (waffle bacon says it all).  Great selection, including gluten free and both soy and almond milk for coffee. Never knew you could do so many different and delicious things with waffles.

Great food, great music, great decor, but TERRIBLE service. Stood at the entrance for 15 min before anyone greeted us, then waited another 15 min before a waiter came to our table. The waiter was also super unfriendly and unaccommodating. We had to wait another 30 min before we were acknowledged to ask for the check. Would not recommend to anyone who values customer service.

There need to be more reviews for this place - I demand it! Highly overlooked brunch spot, and one of two reasons to ever get off at Lansdowne station (Ciro's being the other: http://www.yelp.ca/biz/ciros-toronto). Step over the vagrants that are loafing outside the station and head north a block or two, and you will have arrived.

This is a gourmet waffle cafe with many, many options that will satisfy even the most diehard waffle enthusiast. I've enjoyed The Hitchhiker ($10), which includes scrambled eggs with cheddar cheese, caramelized bacon (I subbed for tomato and avocado slices) and two waffles. I was not a fan of the potato salad (to be fair, I never really am, unless it's my own**), but everything else was on point. There's also a Waffle Benny ($9 for exactly what it sounds like), an AYCE special ($15) and a host of other menu items if (for some reason) you're not in the mood for waffles.


The owners, Tobias and Bryan, are two affable fellows who you'll immediately want to befriend. They play cool music, interesting movies backdrops like the Video Director series, and create all of the photography you see on the walls. They run the show here and do everything from tidying your table to plating your food. They're always trying out new things on the menu and you can even send in suggestions for different waffle types on their website - UGC at its finest!

Cash only, last time I checked.

** Potato Salad recipe: http://food.chatelaine.com/Recipes/View/Dilled_new_potato_salad

This place is quite the spurlge. The eggs Benny are wonderfully some shaped. I really think that it was amazing at how perfect the Benny's turned out. I went for the salmon Benny without any capers and my spouse went for the breakfast Benny made with potatoes in the waffles. Both came with a waffle base instead of a English muffin. After brunch, we had a latte and a cappuccino which were very well made. It came with great sides some salad and a choice of fruit, beans or potato salad. Though the service is kind of slow and there is a lot of people. This is kind of a lazy Sunday kind of venture.

I can't wait to come back to give it 5 stars.
Food was great.  coffee was strong.  CASH ONLY .. atm on the premise.  Service is a little slow which is 4 vs 5. Otherwise love the atmosphere

THEY DO NOT USE REAL MAPLE SYRUP 
they are a Canadian waffle house and they use fructose corn syrup!!!!! 
THEY ARE A WAFFLE HOUSE AND THEY USE FRUCTOSE CORN SYRUP. 
Its so sad, the waffles are not bad but having to put that garbage on my waffles is shameful. 

Also today when i went in there was a half dead cockroach on the floor beneath me. 
the service is okay, the food is good besides THIS SIN 

Literally anytime mentions Starving artist to me they inform me that they do not use real maple syrup. 

cheap. cheap cheap.
Love the food here! Eggs benny with smoked salmon and potatoes waffles was amazing!!!!!

Great place to go with a friend or small group of people. Great options for waffles they have a variety of sweet and savoury on the menu. Decor is nice and the servers are amazing! Sometimes the food is great and sometimes it's alright, it depends on who makes it I think. But it's a good place overall!

This is a response to a recent experience I had overhearing someone deal with a server at this resto. It was not only rude, it was over the line and made me feel like posting a review, which I never do. 

I was at the table next to you on Sunday, and heard you complain loudly and belittle the waitress that, tried as she might to please you, could do little to gain your respect or thanks.

You had to wait 20 mins. Guess what, we all had to wait. It's Sunday, and it's brunch in Toronto - welcome. You had a child with you, and they were hungry. The waitress sat you at the bar and got you drinks, a free waffle for your child to tide them over, and got your food order in, all while you sat and waited. Not so bad I'd say. Even thoughtful and kind.

And then you got your food, finished it, and then complained again to her that it wasn't good, but only after you ate most of it. Hey, I know it's all about you, but you really should try to serve people one day, and get a taste of humanity. It's a life lesson and it teaches you that we're all trying our best, and none of us in the centre of the universe.

Just try to be decent. It goes a long way.

Worth the wait! The st Clair location is pretty big but the line made its way outside even in -20 degrees. Everything is on waffles (which is great) and you cant go wrong with savoury or sweet. The service is friendly and pretty fast. It's a good experience overall!

An interesting concept - to serve everything on waffles.  I ended up getting spicy chicken on waffles because the server said the portion was large and because i was so hungry.  I wasn't sure if the fusion of waffles and spicy chicken as a sandwich would work.  After trying it, my verdict is... meh.  The waffles served as a sponge and absorbed the spicy sauce, so i was cutting into a soggy messy fare.  Just not my thing.  It also came with a choice of fruits or potato salad.  I chose potato salad.  That was good.  We ordered mimosa, and the server brought a bottle of sparkling wine and a bottle of orange juice.  It was up to us to fill our glasses.  My friends and i were like... what should the portion be, so we decided to split 50-50 between the wine and the juice.  
So the service was bare minimum.  And the table we were assigned to had a napkin laying around underneath that should have been picked up when they cleared the table.  The servers were trying to play the role of starving artists i guess with holes in sweaters and generally looking like they couldn't afford to do anything about their appearance.  But for me as a diner, i just prefer eating in a clean, presentable environment.
Last thing.  They take cash only.

The Starving Artist combines all day breakfast foods on waffles with a contemporary artistic atmosphere showcasing work from local artists here in Toronto. Seeing that I am a huge fan of chicken and waffles that was the first thing I looked for on their menu. After all, how can anyone go wrong with the chicken and waffles classic?! If you like brunch and waffles as much as I do for breakfast, lunch and dinner, and want to support the city's local artists, this place is worth checking out!

Get there early or be prepared to wait for a table. Service is also not the quickest, and the servers needed to be prompted for water and when we were ready to order. Food also took a while to be served to us.

I decided to go here for an afternoon brunch with my friends, they supposedly had good reviews, but when I walked in at 3:07 we were directed to our table by a far from friendly wide hipped, curly haired waitress. It took her at least 10 minutes to bring us our cups for the water, with no straws may I add. I asked for lemon to go with my water, and she completely ignored me. It was the first time my group has ever been there so everyone was asking questions about the food; and again the waitress was being extremely disrespectful. So we finally got our order in at 3:17. I kid you not it our food came at 4:07. Remember this place is a waffle place. Waffles by nature take only 5 minutes to makes. When we got our food serviced, I asked the server why did it take an hour to come. She had the nerve to tell me it took 20 minutes and they marked our time down. Even in a busy Resturant like jackastors it doesn't take that long to get food. Then she went to the manager, the manager looked at me and turned away. I swear if it wasn't for the fact that there is so many racial problems right now, I would have went off in there. But non the less I was one West Indian female with three Somali women. We would have been charged just for asking for a discount. 

So my recommendation, don't ever go there unless you want to be treated less then.

Btw...  I USED THEIR WIFI TO WRITE THIS REVIEW

Like short reviews that get straight to the point? Here's one!!

You a waffle person?? Go Starving Artist!! You'll be waffly impressed with the varieties of waffles you can waffle down!!

Great waffles served by charming people, people!

Sitting in one of the most awkward neighborhoods in Toronto - a place where you can order waffles topped with pretty much any of your favorite things. They have amazing coffee/espresso, a cute little licensed patio in the front, and to my surprise...another patio in the back. I was reasonably stuffed, but not overly so, after downing a "waffle benny" - poached eggs, caramelized onions and bacon - with a side of beans and salad. Scrumptious!

This newest location of Starving Artist is located at Davisville and Mount Pleasant, an 8-10 min walk away from Davisville subway station. I was introduced to Starving Artist many years ago at their former Lansdowne location. I had a great experience the first time I went and was excited to try out Starving Artist again at their new location. The place is not big but is suitable for families and very kid friendly. The vibe is relaxing and laid back with friendly service. 

I headed to brunch on a Saturday and arrived at the restaurant around 12:30pm. The place was bustling with customers enjoying their various waffle dishes and my boyfriend and I had to wait around 15 min to get a table. Service was good although it did take them a while to give us water and our coffees. Other than that, the waffle dishes we ordered came at a reasonable time. I ordered the waffle benny while my boyfriend got the monte cristo waffle sandwich. My waffle benny was delicious and came with a side salad and fruit. My boyfriend's monte cristo was filled with ham, turkey and Havarti cheese. We had no complaints about the food and enjoyed our brunch. They also had dessert waffles which looked tempting but we were too full to try them.

Overall, the Starving Artist is a solid place for brunch if you are in the mood for waffles.

Went there today around 1pm with my friend. There were a few empty tables when we first arrived and more people arrived shortly after. The food was excellent but the service was below par. When the food arrived there were no utensils that came with it. We raised our hands up for more than 5 minutes and the waitress never came even though she saw our hands raised. My friends had to go up to ask her for utensils and water, and she still ignored my friend for a few minutes before she actually gave the utensils and water to us; the waitress had my friend bring them to our table which is unacceptable considering it's a full service restaurant. The waitress also wasn't the most polite and was quite emotionless; her speed is comparable to a sloth. When other people came, there were many tables that were not cleaned up, so the guests themselves had to move plates to another table, seat themselves and grab their own menus; some people also left after waiting for more than 10 minutes for a seat at the empty tables. I would've given this place a four star if she atleast greeted us and apologized for the issues that came up. They need more staff on shift.

As a waffle-fiend this place was an absolute dream.
Everything on the menu is waffle-centric while being super accessible (a great variety of gluten-free and vegan stuff).
I had the breakfast sandwich which, while delicious, was a bit small for my ferocious appetite so I would recommend getting one of their full plates. None the less, everything was really affordable by brunch standards.
The one thing I would love to see here is more breakfast cocktails- the really really spicy caesar was divine and I think they could totally up their boozy brunch game with more options.

I came here because I saw amazing photos of this place on Instagram so I decided to have brunch here. 

The lady who served us was very nice and patient when it came to taking our order but once we received our food we rarely saw her, especially when we needed extra plates and napkins. 

I ordered the Starving 4 Waffles with Nutella and Strawberries. It was not bad but not the best, it was average. I also ordered a chocolate milkshake and I didn't like it that much because it tasted like it was just room temperature chocolate milk with Whipped Cream on top. 

The place was very spacious, bright and the decor was pretty. 

Overall, I think the place is only good for taking pictures (food and decor wise). I would only recommend the place if you're looking to take pictures and eating ok waffles.
